annotation.text: Segment 12

Finally I pushed the gate and was very surprised to find it open. I was surprised because it was a few months after the liquidation of nearly all of the ghetto and Jews lived there, the fence was low, everybody could jump over it and on top of that the gate was open.

Someone was passing and I asked him to call Sara. We talked for a short time because it was late, there was a curfew in Warsaw and my way back home would take me at least an hour and a half.

I asked how she managed to survive the liquidation of the ghetto. I had worried about her very much. We were able to help most of our friends. Olga Zweibaum, when she was on the "Aryan" side, called my brother and told him about the terrible round-ups in the ghetto and using our secret code name for courts (in Leszno street) told him that this way of escape was still open. We phoned our friends and most of them managed to escape within the next three days. It was impossible to tell Sara about it because she did not have a telephone and she lived too far from all of my friends to ask anyone to go to her place because of the round-ups. I was afraid she had died because she was never practical in life, did not have much life experience. When I got the postcard from her I was very happy. She told me that it was due to a lot of lucky coincidences that she had survived. Her whole family had been sent to gas chambers.
Segment 13

She was in Dror organization. She managed to escape several times, a few times while she was being marched to Umschlagplatz, once she kicked a German policeman who was dragging her and he fell down the stairs. Anyway she had survived and with the other members of the organization she joined halutzim from the Grochow farm who had been working in Czerniakow estate since the beginning of WW II. I do not know how many of them worked there, a few scores or maybe one hundred people. She told me that the conditions were very harsh. They dug out and ate raw vegetables from the fields in November, they washed themselves in cold water in a pond. Inside their barracks there were only primitive bunks and a few oil lamps. However, they were in a good mood, although they were unsure of their future. I asked them whether they did not want to escape. They told me that, theoretically speaking, they were guarded by an old volksdeutsche but he was a very decent man and he helped them a lot, for instance the postcard I had got had been sent by him. A lot of them tried escaping but they did not have addresses to go to in Warsaw and they did not know where there were partisans. Besides, they thought that most of them had bad accent or bad "looks" (pronounced semitic features). Most of those who had tried escaping were caught. She, herself, [Sara] had already been at the station but had returned because she was afraid of trying to escape. Only then, at the gate and while talking to her, did I realize the degree of isolation of Jews in the Polish society. It was not the walls but the fact that they did not have addresses and even if they had had the addresses they would not have been able to get there without help. There was an enormous difference between them and the assimilated Jews. Assimilated Jews, our friends, often lived in our apartment staying for a night or for a few weeks or months. Only in Czerniakow did I realize how isolated these two societies were although they had been living together, side by side, for one thousand years. I told her I was unable to take her to my apartment at the moment because someone from the ghetto, Hanka Szapiro-Sawicka, had already been staying in it. Every few days Hanka would come and stay for the night. However, I told her to come immediately to me if she was in danger. Later I was very ashamed that I told her that because I should have known better that it is impossible to escape in the last minute and one should escape much earlier.
Segment 14

I visited her two more times and later when I went to see her around Christmas time, carrying a parcel for her, nobody was there. I asked the same woman in the nearby house for information about them but she only told me that they had been marched somewhere a few days before. Later someone told me that they had been marched to a small camp in which the conditions were terrible, i.e. they were treated in the same way as Russian prisoners of war: they were to live in winter without barracks and they were dying of cold. I knew about the conditions in the camps for captured Russian  soldiers because my father who had a good camera used to go to the numerous apartments in which 150 Russian escapees hid and he took pictures which were necessary to procure Polish documents for them. Later these Russian soldiers joined AL (Armia Ludowa, People's Army) partisans. I also took pictures and twice I had a very difficult task because I had to take pictures of two Mongols in such a way that the pictures did not show they were Mongols but, on the other hand, the pictures had to resemble them.

So I got the information that Sara and other people were in such a camp and they all died of hunger. Fortunately, it turned out it was not true.

Different people visited or lived in our apartment. Hanka Szapiro-Sawicka often slept in our apartment and every Wednesday her father, who had assumed the name of Boleslaw Sadowski, visited her in our apartment. They loved each other very much and tried to spent a lot of time together. In August 1942, when Mr. Szapiro came to us he had a high temperature. He stayed in our place and it turned out that it was typhus. Hanka stayed a lot of hours by his bed. Kazio Zweibaum-- presently prof. Zakrzewski-- who had already been a doctor was with him a lot time too. Later we had to bury Bernard Szapiro. Then Hanka Szapiro-Sawicka was arrested. After her death a lot of informers came to our apartment pretending they were conspirators)so my parents decided to send me out of Warsaw  and I stayed at my friend's near Deblin for a few weeks.
Segment 15

At the beginning I belonged to ZWM and all people who belonged to ZWM were counted as members of AL but I did not take part in fighting until Warsaw Uprising (in 1944) and I was only responsible for education.

In early spring in 1943 when I worked in Zoloborz (Warsaw quarter) an unknown young man came to my apartment, he did not give his name to my mother, he only said he wanted to talk to me. Next time he brought a letter from Sara who asked me to procure documents for her no matter what the cost might be. I did not quite understand it but, anyway, I could not do anything without a photograph. Then Frania Razmus, a ZOB (Zydowska Organizacja Bojowa, Jewish Fighting Organization) liaison officer, came to my apartment. She looked like a peasant fourteen year old girl, in fact she was sixteen. She did not have a trace of bad accent or "look". She was very courageous. She was to bring the photographs and money for the documents and Sara was to come to our apartment before Easter (1943). As I have already mentioned I had to leave Warsaw for a few weeks. When I was at my friend's I got news about the outbreak of the Ghetto Uprising. Of course there were conflicting stories. Some people said that the uprising ended on the next day while other people told that Jews captured Pawiak (German prison in Warsaw) and Poles joined them and there was a general uprising at the moment.

When I was on my way home I was even hoping to find Sara at home. My whole family worried about the fate of the uprising. I worked in Zoliborz and lived in Mokotow  so I passed Plac Krasinskich (Krasinskis' Square) every day and that famous merry-go-round (a merry-go-round, with a very loud music, placed by Germans next to the ghetto in order to drown down the sounds of fighting in the ghetto and distract the attention of Poles) I saw twice every day.

Once I also witnessed how a workman got out of an open entrance to the sewage system and he said to a group of people surrounding the entrance that he had set a trap for Jews: a bunch of hand grenades was put inside and when Jews would be passing the grenades would explode. I remember the same feeling as I had already experienced  when I had witnessed how Germans had tortured an old Jew and cut his beard, the feeling of being powerless and helpless. Fifteen months later I myself was passing the same entrance during the Warsaw Uprising.
Segment 16

At that time I did not know other people from ZOB, I knew only Sara. When I came back to Warsaw there was no message from Sara. I worked in Zoliborz and one day when I returned home my mother told me that Sara had come. She must have attracted a lot of attention  because she had walked in sewage canals for 18 hours, than spent ten days in a forest without washing herself, covered with lice and having nothing to eat. She was very exhausted so she took a shower and went to bed. It was May 10, 1943. She came with the first group of 40 people who stayed for the night in Ogrodowa street. Later Kazik helped them to get to Lomianki (Warsaw suburb). PPR (Polska Partia Robotnicza Polish Workers' Party) had failed to help. Then a lorry was to take them further but it did not arrive and they sat there, with guns and no food and water. They were afraid to go to the wells in this village because dogs barked. Those who did not look semitic went to buy some bread but they could not buy much without attracting attention to themselves. Finally, a farmer discovered them and he took care of them bringing food and water; however, he could not bring much either without attracting too much attention.
Segment 17

Since nobody knew any addresses so Sara told them she could go to me to stay while trying to organize some help. She had to walk without her shoes because it was impossible to put them on after walking the canals. When she woke up and said she had to go back but I told her she was too weak so I would settle everything and for the next few days I took care of ZOB matters. Later different liaison officers came. I remember Kazik talking about his trip to the ghetto in order to find his comrades (he describes it in his book).

Sara stayed about two or two and a half months in our apartment. She sometimes left our apartment. She did not follow any rules of conspiration, both at home and outside. If she met anyone she knew, either belonging to our family or our friends, she would gushily greet them in the middle of the street, endangering them. We did not fear that our neighbors could inform the police, however there was one family who, if they knew she was staying with us, would demand from us to get rid of her.  They used to put a lot of pressure on us, for instance telling us not to feed Jewish children who sometimes came to our apartment. So, apart from the janitor and our friends nobody knew about her.

Later Sara moved to an apartment in Rembertow [Warsaw suburb] which was rented by ZOB. I think she lived there with Luba and she was shot by a German policeman while she was there. I do not know how exactly it happened because I heard a few different stories. Anyway, one day when, luckily, I had taken my day off at work the doorbell at my door rang at around 8 o'clock-- I would normally have been on my way to work then-- and when I opened the door I saw Sara who looked terrible, her face was green. Barely whispering she told me that she had been shot "a little" by a German policeman. When I took her to the bathroom I saw that "a little" meant that she had one hole next to her navel and another hole in her back (holes the size of a finger). She survived because she had a navy blue dress. The blood was on her dress, from waist down but fortunately it looked like dirt. First she had been unconscious, later she had spent the night lying next to the pool and drinking water out of it (although you are not supposed to do it when you have been shot in stomach). In the morning she managed to get to the bus stop-- 4 kilometres (about 2.5 miles) she had done in four hours, and without documents and tickets she went by two streetcars, crossing the whole Warsaw, to our house. It was an unbelievable feat.
Segment 18

My mother immediately called my father who was at work and we also called a surgeon we knew, we said that my mother had appendicitis. In an hour's time Dr Jurewicz came and told us that a few people were stopped by Germans at a bus stop and although they seemed only to be checking documents, the doctor's among others, Germans nevertheless took only my father so, he added, they could be here any minute.  We were not sure whether father had finished distributing illegal bulletins. He might have still had them on him.

Doctor told us that immediate surgery was needed. When he was alone with my mother and me he told us that there was little chance that Sara might survive the surgery since 14 hours had passed since she was shot. It was the day that stands out in my memory as far as the war period is concerned. Even the days of Warsaw Uprising I remember less vividly. It is so because at this moment everything depended on me. During the war I could not change the place in which bombs fell, but in this particular case everything depended on my presence of mind and quick acting. I even discussed that with Kazik and I told him that there are two reasons for which I remember it more vividly than other events: I wrote about Sara a few years after the war-- that was the first version of my book; it was finally published in 1958-- while he described his recollections after 40 years and for him, anyway, Sara was only a small episode while for me it was a very important event.
Segment 19

Doctor promised to try to find a place in a hospital for her and I went to Wola (Warsaw quarter) hospital in Plocka (street) to a young doctor I knew. It was a miracle, if I had come to the hospital a minute later he would have already left. I told him everything. She did not have her documents-- the documents she had carried were authentic documents of a deceased person and the German policeman had probably kept them. He agreed to admit her to the hospital and he said that he would warn some of the personnel and added that she was to tell everybody that some old women found her in the street and brought her to the hospital. She was never to mention our names.

I hurried home; streetcars were very slow but going on foot would be even slower. On my way home I went to my friends and asked them to give as much money as they could explaining that there was a possibility that we would have to bribe German policemen-- my friends had a firm so they had money. They gave me the money and I quickly hopped into a streetcar. When I got off the streetcar and was running home I suddenly stopped before the last corner because I was afraid there might have been German police cars waiting for me in front of the house. Fortunately, I did not see any.

When I got home Sara's condition had worsened. I said I had found a place in a hospital and we had to take Sara there immediately. My mother had already asked her friend, who was called Chodak, nee Wiederschal, a Jewess, and my father's sister. We dressed her in my clothes and called a horse cab. When the cabman saw Sara's face he only said:" I would better put the hood up", and it was a very fine, hot and sunny day but we went with the hood on. He did not say a word more.
Segment 20

There were problems with the admission to the hospital, probably not everybody had been informed. As regards the surgery, later it became a topic of doctor's discussions in Warsaw. It was so unbelievable that it had been successful.

Sara did not behave cautiously. It was not her fault that she talked Yiddish when she was unconscious and in fever but she was very irresponsible later. The next night after the surgery she got up and drank some water although she was told not to. However, the worst thing was that later, when she was fully conscious, she gave our names and phone number, she asked everybody about us. We kept in touch with her indirectly, asking other people to pass news to her, and we told her many times that we know everything about her and asked her not to inquire about us but she did anyway.
Segment 21

It was against all rules of conspiracy-- and she had been in conspiracy long enough to know that, it was in 1943. A few weeks after she had left the hospital there was a deportation. Most of the doctors were taken to Oswiecim. Grzela Gromkowski, the doctor who admitted her to the hospital died in Oswiecim. I talked to Dr.Tetmajer a few days ago. She remembers Sara. She told me that Jews and wounded partisans had been admitted to the hospital and there had always been two or three Jews or partisans at the hospital.  It was done while there was a general German order that all hospitals were to notify Germans whenever a wounded person was admitted to a hospital. Anyway, this hospital had functioned for a miraculously long time, till the middle of 1943.

Germans kept my father so my mother and I knew that the house should be "clean". For many days we combed the house getting rid of all old underground bulletins and other illegal things, among others we found a forgotten old ghetto arm band one year after the ghetto had been liquidated. We learnt that father was at Szucha (German prison in Aleja Szucha, in Warsaw). We supposed that he had not had any illegal bulletins on him but we knew that it was impossible to take Sara to our apartment at that moment. We had also lost the contact with ZOB, we did not have any addresses. We-- my mother, my aunt and I-- hoped that someone would think of contacting us.  Unfortunately, when they did, another aunt of mine, the one who did not know about anything, answered the phone and when someone asked about Krysia [Sara's new name] she said nobody knew anyone of that name and asked that person not to call any more. We nearly fell in despair because Grzela called us every day asking us to take Sara back because she was endangering the whole hospital.
Segment 22

Fortunately, there was this Gypsy, telling Kazik his fortune, and she told him that Krysia was in hospital (the story is described in the book "Mur mial dwie strony"). So they called us again and Irka called too and she took Sara to an apartment in 5, Panska street. I did not go to see Sara, I saw her only later during the Warsaw Uprising, in 1944, but Kazik would give us information about her. He told us that she was all right although still weak. She had had to be taken from the hospital sooner but her health was improving.

I met Kazik for the first time when he visited Sara. He was a very joyful boy. He had spent his childhood among urchins in Powisle [Warsaw quarter], he lived in Podchorazych street, all his friends were "Aryan" so he spoke with "Powisle accent", he did not have a trace of Jewish accent, did not look or behave like a Jew and, like in the case of Frania, nobody could tell he was Jewish. They were very good liaison officers. Frania's name was Beatus, I am sorry I had mixed up names when I had talked about Frania before. Razmus was a name or some other woman. She was Frania Beatus.
